awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Solar-Powered Unmanned Aerial and Ground Vehicles for Long-Term Operation in Dynamic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Current technology in solar-powered robotic systems is limited to homogeneous robots that act independently within the constraints of their design and are subject to power limitations and inability to intelligently adapt to changeable situations. These limitations prevent the widespread adoption of solar robots in applications. This career project proposes a transformative approach to the development of next generation solar-powered robotic systems that overcome these limitations. An innovative strategy will integrate heterogeneous aerial and ground vehicle operations in order to accomplish long-duration high-efficiency missions, improve adaptability to dynamic environments, and enable the effective use of environmental but variable energy sources. Results of this work will enable societally-important technological advancements in environmental monitoring, search and rescue, surveillance, and agriculture, which will contribute to U.S. economic vitality, public health, and security. This research also provides necessary insights into general robotics applications pertaining to alleviating the dependence of robotic missions on non-renewable energy sources during long-duration operations. The use and application of solar-powered robots increases the demand for high-quality photovoltaic products, which will subsequently boost development in related technologies. This work will incorporate a hierarchy of educational activities appropriate to different groups of students, from the general public to more advanced scholars. These activities include a synergy-based education platform, industry-oriented training projects, and educational open-source software for a solar robot. In collaboration with the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research team at Iowa State University, the PI will provide public visitors, especially community college and K-12 students, with access to robotic systems.

The research will contribute to a novel paradigm enabling experimentation on energy-aware long-duration autonomous multi-platform systems. Establishing advanced autonomy in solar-powered robotic systems will be accomplished by leveraging interdisciplinary methodologies in the fields of dynamic networks, distributed control, and convex optimization, and by developing novel strategies for coordinating and controlling heterogeneous aerial and ground vehicles toward mission accomplishment. These multidisciplinary methodologies will be consistently integrated to yield a new paradigm for modeling, optimization, and distributed control of solar-powered robotic systems. The project will systematically infuse solar energy into a demanding technological area, namely robotic systems, with specific applications to wide-area long-duration operations. The proposed optimization and control schemes will address fundamental problems of multi-agent dynamical systems whose performance can be improved by cooperation among internal agents.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project developed the next-generation solar-powered robotic systems that are capable of harvesting solar energy from the environments to realize long terms operations. The outcomes include three types of robotic platforms that integrate autonomous energy harvesting and power management functions and optimization algorithms for solving general nonconvex optimization problems. The three types of robotic platforms include (1) a solar-powered ground vehicle that can work independently or collaborate with existing outdoor robots as a mobile charging station, (2) two generations of solar-powered quadcopters with much-extended flight duration by harvesting ambient energy, (3) a solar-powered lighter-than-air robot that is capable of gaining all required operational power from environments. Moreover, integrated power management and mission planning strategy, together with energy situation awareness capability, have been developed for the robotic platforms to achieve full-level autonomy while accomplishing long-term operations. The other focus of outcomes is the development of optimization algorithms that have been applied to solve a wide range of nonconvex optimization problems, including (1) motion planning and decision-making of complicated dynamical systems, (2) large-scale data synthesis, (3) network topology design, and (4) sensor network localization.

Intellectual Merit: The solar-powered ground and aerial vehicles proved the feasibility of long-term operations by carefully planning the robotic system motion while harvesting energy from the environment. It also verifies that by integrating a solar-powered robot into an existing robot team, it will improve the mobility and success rate of the robot team in outdoor missions. The developed optimization algorithms are highly implementable and thus have wide applications. Furthermore, the optimization algorithms can accommodate logical decision variables, which improves the autonomy level of dynamic systems.

Broader Impacts: Any robotic system that can access solar energy can beneﬁt from the outcomes of this project. By demonstrating the feasibility of long-term (even persistent) operation of the solar-powered robot in multi-waypoint traveling missions, it verifies the applicability in specific missions requiring long duration traveling, e.g., environmental monitoring, search and rescue, surveillance, and farming. By integrating the designed expereimental testbed in curriculum development, the PI created hands-on experience for engineering students in control fields. Moreover, the PI provided research opportunities for undergraduate students who have enthusiasm for robotics research. The outreach activities attracted more students to STEM, especially female students, provided educational opportunities to the public audience to learn the special functions of robotic systems.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Ran Dai

por.por_txt_cntn:
This project developed the next-generation solar-powered robotic systems that are capable of harvesting solar energy from the environments to realize long terms operations. The outcomes include three types of robotic platforms that integrate autonomous energy harvesting and power management functions and optimization algorithms for solving general nonconvex optimization problems. The three types of robotic platforms include (1) a solar-powered ground vehicle that can work independently or collaborate with existing outdoor robots as a mobile charging station, (2) two generations of solar-powered quadcopters with much-extended flight duration by harvesting ambient energy, (3) a solar-powered lighter-than-air robot that is capable of gaining all required operational power from environments. Moreover, integrated power management and mission planning strategy, together with energy situation awareness capability, have been developed for the robotic platforms to achieve full-level autonomy while accomplishing long-term operations. The other focus of outcomes is the development of optimization algorithms that have been applied to solve a wide range of nonconvex optimization problems, including (1) motion planning and decision-making of complicated dynamical systems, (2) large-scale data synthesis, (3) network topology design, and (4) sensor network localization.

Intellectual Merit: The solar-powered ground and aerial vehicles proved the feasibility of long-term operations by carefully planning the robotic system motion while harvesting energy from the environment. It also verifies that by integrating a solar-powered robot into an existing robot team, it will improve the mobility and success rate of the robot team in outdoor missions. The developed optimization algorithms are highly implementable and thus have wide applications. Furthermore, the optimization algorithms can accommodate logical decision variables, which improves the autonomy level of dynamic systems.

Broader Impacts: Any robotic system that can access solar energy can beneﬁt from the outcomes of this project. By demonstrating the feasibility of long-term (even persistent) operation of the solar-powered robot in multi-waypoint traveling missions, it verifies the applicability in specific missions requiring long duration traveling, e.g., environmental monitoring, search and rescue, surveillance, and farming. By integrating the designed expereimental testbed in curriculum development, the PI created hands-on experience for engineering students in control fields. Moreover, the PI provided research opportunities for undergraduate students who have enthusiasm for robotics research. The outreach activities attracted more students to STEM, especially female students, provided educational opportunities to the public audience to learn the special functions of robotic systems.
